--- title: "Data, DataViz, and Stats with the Stars" author: "Arvind V." date: 28-June-2025 order: 1 format: revealjs: theme: [default, styles.css] chalkboard: false incremental: false preview-links: auto scrollable: true slide-number: true show-slide-number: print embed-resources: true touch: true controls: true controls-layout: edges footer: "Arvind V.| VizChitra2025 | June 2025" html-math-method: katex # include-in-header: # - text: '' ### # webcam: # toggleKey: "W" # Change the key to toggle the video # enabled: false # Enable the video stream directly at startup. Pressing [W] will still allow you to toggle it. # persistent: false # Keep the stream open (the camera active) after opening it once. If it is enabled the plugin will keep the camera on even if the video is not used. This avoids repeat permission request dialogs. ### pointer: key: "q" color: "green" pointerSize: 48 alwaysVisible: false ### revealjs-plugins: # - animate-graph # - revealjs-text-resizer - pointer # - excalidraw # - webcam # - drop # console drop-down # not working at all # - spotlight # - subtitles # works, but not needed filters: - highlight-text #colour #bg-colour #fg - gadenbuie/tachyons --- ## Agenda! - Orange? What is this Orange stuff, anyhow? - Throwing it All Away with Brad Pitt: Data Summaries - Counting Letters with Sherlock Holmes: Bar Charts - Nursery Rhymes with Ben Affleck: Line Charts - Being a Mermaid with Katie Ledecky: Box Plots - Jack and Rose lived happily ever after: Mosaic Plots - The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh: Permutation Tests ::: notes {{< downloadthis data/penguins.csv dname="penguins.csv" label="Download the Penguins data" icon="database-fill-down" type="info" >}} datasaurus_dozen %>% download_this(output_name = "datasaurus", output_extension = ".csv", button_label = "DataSaurus Dirty Dozen", button_type = "default", icon = "fa fa-save", class = "hvr-sweep-to-left") ::: --- ## Setup {visibility="hidden"} ::: {.cell} ::: --- ## Orange? What is this Orange stuff, anyhow? {.center} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="30%"} **Orange** is a visual drag-and-drop tool for - Data visualization - Statistical Tests - Machine Learning - Data mining and much more. ::: ::: {.column width="65%} ![Orange Data Mining GUI](https://orangedatamining.com/screenshots/tree-explorative.png){#fig-orange-datamining-gui height=400 width=760} You can download and install Orange from here: ::: :::: --- ## Basic Usage of Orange :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} {{< video https://youtu.be/HXjnDIgGDuI height=540 width=760 >}} ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} {{< video https://youtu.be/lb-x36xqJ-E height=540 width=760 >}} ::: :::: --- ## Widgets and Channels :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} {{< video https://youtu.be/2xS6QjnG714 height=540 width=760 title='None of them!'>}} ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} {{< video https://youtu.be/MHcGdQeYCMg height=540 width=760 title='None of them!'>}} ::: :::: --- ## The Orange Visual Interface Let us create some simple visualizations using Orange. - Use the `File Widget` to import the `iris` dataset into your session - Use the `Data Table Widget` to look at the data, and note its variable names - Use the `Visualization Widgets` ( Scatter Plot, Bar Plot, and Distributions) to look at the properties of the variables, and examine relationships between them. --- ## What does Data Look like? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ![Variable Types](../../../../materials/images/fig-variables-1.png){height=440} ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![Tidy Data](../../../../materials/images/tidydata.jpg){height=440} ::: :::: --- ## Orange Practice Session#1{.smaller} ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - Let's use the `Datasets` widget - Click on it to select one of the built-in CSV files : `Auto MPG` - Let's look at the Data using the `Data Table` widget - And create a Scatter Plot with the `Scatter Plot` widget (Horsepower vs Displacement) - Try the menu options on the left side to see how they alter the plot ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![](images/scatterplot.png){height=400 width=550} ::: :::: ::: notes Look at the data table to see the variable names, and the data types. ::: --- ## Brad Pitt: Throwing it All Away {.center} --- ## Brad Pitt: Throwing it All Away
{{< video https://youtu.be/PlKDQqKh03Y height=580 width=820 title='None of them!'>}}
::: notes What was Brad Pitt throwing away? He was throwing away the individuality of the measures, subsuming them to one summary. This is a big idea in statistics, and it is called aggregation. ::: --- ## A Pillar of Statistical Wisdom{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="65%"} Steven Stigler (2016) in “The Seven Pillars of Statistical Wisdom”: - One of the Big Ideas in Statistics is: ***Aggregation*** - How is it revolutionary? - By stipulating that, given a number of observations, [you can actually gain information by throwing information away]{.bg-light-red .black} - In taking a simple arithmetic mean, we discard the individuality of the measures, subsuming them to one summary. ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](../../../../materials/images/SevenPillarsStigler.jpeg){width=300} ::: :::: --- ## Brad Pitt: Throwing it All Away ### What was he throwing away? :::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### All the "Variables" - Age - Previous Seasons - Waist Size - Treadmill Test Score - Bat Speed? - Smoke Weed? - Girlfriend? - Girlfriend Looks Rating? - Waddles like a Duck? - Looks Weird? ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### And he was looking ONLY at... ![OBP Data](../../../../materials/images/OBP.png){height=300} ::: ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify fe beginner >}} How do we throw away data?{.smaller}
{{< iconify material-symbols table-chart-outline size=3x >}} {{< iconify tabler ruler-measure size=3x >}} {{< iconify lucide square-sigma size=3x >}}
Before we plot a single chart, it is wise to take a look at several numbers that summarize the dataset under consideration. What might these be? Some obviously useful numbers are: - Dataset length: How many rows/observations? - Dataset breadth: How many columns/variables? - How many Quant variables? - How many Qual variables? - Quant variables: min, max, mean, median, sd - Qual variables: levels, counts per level - Both: means, medians for each level of a Qual variable... --- ## Orange Practice Session #2{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - So what do ***we*** throw away now? And how? ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} - Let's look at the existing dataset, `Auto MPG` - Pull in the `Feature Statistics` widget - Connect the `Datasets` widget to the `Feature Statistics` widget - Appreciate the Summary Statistics that are generated ::: :::: --- ## Wait, But Why?{.smaller} ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - **To summarize is to understand**. - Add to that the fact that our [Working Memories can hold maybe 7 items](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/The_Magical_Number_Seven,_Plus_or_Minus_Two), so it means information retention too. - Borges wrote, “To think is to **forget details, generalize, make abstractions**. In the teeming world of [“Funes the Memorious,”](https://www.sas.upenn.edu/~cavitch/pdf-library/Borges_FunesTheMemorious.pdf), there were only details.” - Brad Pitt aka Billy Beane was throwing away the details, and looking at the **aggregated** picture to pick his future Oakland A's team. ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![](images/summary-table.png){height=400 width=650} ::: :::: ::: notes ::: --- ## Counting Letters with Sherlock Holmes {.center} --- ## Sherlock Holmes: The Adventure of the Dancing Men :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} In the Sherlock Holmes story, [The Adventure of the Dancing Men](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/108/108-h/108-h.htm#chap03), a criminal known to one of the characters communicates with her using a childish/child-like drawing which looks like this: ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![Am Here, Abe Slaney](../../../../materials/images/holmes-message-1.jpg) How would Holmes decipher this message? ::: :::: --- ## Sherlock Holmes: The Adventure of the Dancing Men{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} - Using Conjectures: - Symbols -> Letters - Based on well-known ***Counts*** of letters (Zipf's Law) - Holmes deduces that the most common letter in the message is "E" - He then deduces that the second most common letter is "T" ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ![Zipf's Law](../../../../materials/images/zipf.png){height=480} ::: :::: --- ## What Charts work for counting?{.smaller} | Variable #1 | Variable #2 | Chart Names | Chart Shape | |:-----------:|:-----------:|:-----------:|:-------------------------------------:| | Qual | None | Bar Chart | {{< iconify ion bar-chart size=4x >}} | - Bar charts are used to show "counts" and "tallies" with respect to Qual variables. - For instance, in a survey, how many people vs Gender? - In a Target Audience survey on *Weekly Consumption*, how many low, medium, or high expenditure people? - NOTE: we count with Qual variables! (Why? We count labels, like letters.) - Which is why the Bars are not touching each other. --- ## Orange Practice Session #3 #### Banned Books!!! ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} OK, Let's get some data to count: Banned Books Data And let's for now use a pre-set Workflow in Orange Barchart Workflow ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} - We will look at the data - Make a Data dictionary - Identify the Qual and Quant variables - Prepare Counts and Bar Charts wrt Qual variables - In Orange! Point, Click, and See! ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify streamline dictionary-language-book-solid >}} Data Dictionary{.smaller} #### Qualitative Variables - `Author`: Author of the book (Qual) - `Title`: Title of the book (Qual) - `Origin`: Origin of the Challenge (Qual) - `Type of Ban`: Type of ban on the book (Qual) - `State`: State in which the book was banned (Qual) - `District`: District in which the book was banned (Qual) - `Origin`: Origin of the Challenge (Qual) #### Quantitative Variables - None --- ## {{< iconify material-symbols query-stats >}} Counting our Data :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### Research Question Do some States ban more books than some others? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note #### What is the Story Here? - Texas is the worst at book banning! - Texas, Florida, Oklahoma, Kansas, Indiana,..are next in line - Is there a "Bible Belt" story here? ![Bible Belt](../../../../materials/images/BibleBelt.png){#fig-bible-belt} ::: ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify material-symbols query-stats >}} Counting our Data :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### Research Question What are the kinds of bans that are being imposed on books? How many books banned by each type of ban? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note #### What is the Story Here? - Four reasons for banning books - "Investigation" is the commonest kind of ban - How does one "investigate" a book??? ::: ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify mingcute thought-line >}} Wait, But Why? - Counts first give you **an absolute sense of how much data you have**. - Counts by different Qual variables give you a sense of the **combinations** you have in your data: $(State) * (District) * (Ban)$ - Counts then give an idea whether your data is lop-sided - Since the X-axis in bar charts is *Qualitative* (the bars don't touch, remember!) it is possible to sort the bars at will. --- ## Nursery Rhymes with Ben Affleck {.center} --- ## Nursery Rhymes with Ben Affleck{.smaller} ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - In "The Accountant," Christian Wolff is heard reciting "Solomon Grundy," - The nursery rhyme tells the life and death of a man named Solomon Grundy, **all within a single week**. - It was innocently used to help children learn their days of the week. - However, when we look into the fact that Thursday through Sunday detail the tragic end of Mr. Grundy due to an unspecified illness... - it's hard to ignore the dark undertones. ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![](../../../../materials/images/christian-recites-the-tale-of-solomon-grundy-1643128496.webp){height=360 width=500} ::: :::: --- ## What is the Data here? And the Chart?{.smaller} ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - The data is the **days of the week**. - The data is **the number of events that happen on each day**. - The y-variable is a Quant variable, a number - The x-variable is also Quant variable, a ***time*** variable ::: callout-note Tourist: Any famous people born around here?
Guide: No sir, best we can do is babies. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![Line Chart for Time Series](images/R17XS-the-rise-of-google-chrome.png){height=400 width=500} ::: :::: --- ## Timing our Data ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} OK, Let's get some data to chart: Born in the USA Data And let's for now use a pre-set Workflow in Orange Time Series Workflow ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} - We will look at the data - Make a Data dictionary - Identify the Qual and Quant variables - Prepare Time Series Charts with Quant variables, and Qual variables ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify streamline dictionary-language-book-solid >}} Data Dictionary{.smaller} ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} #### Qualitative Variables - `year`: Year of birth (Qual) - `month`: Month of the year (Qual) - `day_of_month`: Day of the month (Qual) - `day_of_week`: Day of the week (Qual) #### Quantitative Variables - `births`: Number of births on that day (Quant) ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 5 year month date_of_month day_of_week births 1 2000 1 1 6 9083 2 2000 1 2 7 8006 3 2000 1 3 1 11363 4 2000 1 4 2 13032 5 2000 1 5 3 12558 6 2000 1 6 4 12466 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: --- ## Orange Practice Session#4{.smaller} ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - The data is the number of births in the USA, by day, month, and year - Let us use the `Group By` widget to group by `day_of_week` - AND compute the `mean(births)` in the same widget - We plot the `mean(births)` vs `month`, and colour by `day_of_week` ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![Mean Births Time Series](images/births-time-series.png){height=400 width=500} ::: :::: --- ## Wait, But Why?{.smaller} ::::{.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - Time series data is a special kind of Quantitative data, where the x-variable is a time variable. - The y-variable is a Quant variable, a number. - The x-variable is a Quant variable, a ***time*** variable. - By colouring by `day_of_week`, we can see how the number of births varies by day of the week. ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} #### What is the Story Here? - Could there be a staffing shortage at hospitals on weekends? - Is this a "revealed preference" thing? - Or should we watch Grey's Anatomy, or even House? ::: :::: --- ## Being a Mermaid with Katie Ledecky {.center} --- ## Being a Mermaid with Katie Ledecky --- ## Jack and Rose lived happily ever after {.center} --- ## Jack and Rose lived happily ever after? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - The Titanic sank on 15 April 1912, after hitting an iceberg. - What are the chances that Jack survived too? - What did his chances depend on? ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](../../../../materials/images/titanic.webp){height=400} ::: :::: --- ## Jack and Rose lived happily ever after? - Let's get the `titanic` data, using the `Datasets` widget in Orange. - There were 2201 passengers, as per this dataset. - And let's use a pre-set Workflow in Orange Mosaic Chart Workflow --- ### {{< iconify streamline dictionary-language-book-solid >}} Data Dictionary: `titanic`{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### Quantitative Data None. ::: ::: callout-note ### Qualitative Data - `survived`: (chr) yes or no - `status`: (chr) Class of Travel, else "crew" - `age`: (chr) Adult, Child - `sex`: (chr) Male / Female. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![](../../../../materials/images/Orange/titanic-data-table.png){height=500 width=450} ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify tabler variable >}} What kind of Data Variables will we choose? | Variable #1 | Variable #2 | Chart Names | Chart Shape | |:---------------:|:---------------:|:-----------------:|:------------------:| | Qual | Qual | ~~Pies~~, Mosaic Charts | {{< iconify carbon chart-marimekko size=4x >}} | Here, $area \sim count$, so the area of the tile is proportional to the count of observations in that tile. --- ### {{< iconify material-symbols query-stats >}} Research Question #1{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note What is the dependence of `survived` upon `sex`? ::: ![](../../../../materials/images/Orange/titanic-sex-survived.png) ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note - Note the huge imbalance in `survived` with `sex` - Men have clearly perished in larger numbers than women. - Colouring shows large [*positive* residuals]{style="color: blue;"} for men who died, and large [*negative* residuals]{style="color: red;"} for women who died. So sadly Jack is far more likely to have died than Rose. ::: ::: :::: --- ### {{< iconify material-symbols query-stats >}} Research Question #2{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### How does `survived` depend upon `status`? ::: ![](../../../../materials/images/Orange/titanic-mosaic-survived-status.png) ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note - Crew has seen deaths in large numbers, - as seen by the large [*negative* residual]{style="color: red;"} for crew-survivals. - [First Class passengers have had speedy access to the boats](https://youtu.be/kQ8WsD9AGX4) and have survived in larger proportions than say second or third class. - There is a large [*positive* residual]{style="color: blue;"} for first-class survivals. - Rose travelled `first class` and Jack was `third class`. So again the odds are stacked against him. ::: ::: :::: --- ## What are these Residuals anyhow?{.smaller} When differences between the actual and expected counts are large, we deduce that one Qual variable has an effect on the other Qual variable. (speaking counts-wise or ratio-wise) ::: {.cell layout-ncol="3"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Actual Counts](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Expected Counts!!](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-2.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Tile-Wise Differences = Residuals](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-3.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh {.center} --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh
{{< video https://youtu.be/chi9hsfYcDE height=500 width=760 title='Kamaal ho Gaya!' >}}
--- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - What was the "data" Gabbar was looking at? Chamber | Bullet ------------- | ------------- 1 | Y / N 2 | Y / N .. | ... 6 | Y / N ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} - The number of people in the village, and the number of people who were armed. (Quant) - The number of bullets in the gun (Quant) - The ID of the pistol chamber which contains a bullet (Qual) ::: :::: --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh And Gabbar's Hypothesis? - That three bullets would never line up just ready to be fired, especially after he had fired three off!! - So he could claim "ignorance"! - "Ignorance" == "Fairness" == "Justice" ! - But he was surprised when the three bullets were lined up, and he could fire them all off at once! - But no one could accuse him of anything, because he was "ignorant" of the fact that the bullets were lined up! --- ## Gabbar's Gun Permutations ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## So how do we become Gabbar Singh? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: callout-note ### [Are Emily and Greg more Employable than Lakisha and Jamal?](https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/Rdatasets/doc/AER/ResumeNames.html) Is ethnicity (as revealed byfirst names) a basis for racial discrimination, in the US? This dataset was generated as part of a landmark research study done by [Marianne Bertrand and Senthil Mullainathan](https://sci-hub.se/10.1257/0002828042002561). Read the description therein to really understand how you can ***prove causality*** with a well-crafted research experiment. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell messsage='false'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 3 name ethnicity call 1 Allison cauc no 2 Kristen cauc no 3 Lakisha afam no 4 Latonya afam no 5 Carrie cauc no 6 Jay cauc no ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 × 3 # Groups: ethnicity [2] ethnicity call n 1 afam yes 157 2 afam no 2278 3 cauc yes 235 4 cauc no 2200 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 2 ethnicity call_prop 1 afam 6.45 2 cauc 9.65 ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` diffprop 0.108199 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - So it appears the call percentage is different for the two ethnicities, `afam` and `cauc` - But is it statistically significant? Would Gabbar be surprised? - Let us pretend `ethnicity` ***does not matter*** and spin the revolver!! - We mess with the ethnicity variable, some 5000 times ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "diffprop" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: :::: --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh{.smaller} Gabbar | Stats Teacher ------------- | ------------- “Kitne aadmi thay?” | How many observations do you have? n < 30 is a joke. Kya Samajh kar aaye thay? Gabbar khus hoga? Sabaasi dega kya? | What are the levels in your Factors? Are they binary? Don’t do ANOVA just yet! (Fires off three rounds ) Haan, ab theek hai! | Yes, now the dataset is balanced wrt the factor (Treatment and Control). Is pistol mein teen zindagi aur teen maut bandh hai. Dekhte hain kisko kya milega. | This is our Research Question, for which we will Design an Experiment. Hume kuchh nahi pataa! | Let us perform a non-parametric Permutation Test for this Factor! Kamaal ho gaya! | Fantastic! Our p-value is so small that we can reject the NULL Hypothesis!! --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh Let us look at Senthil Mullainathan's work on Hiring vs Race.

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
